maml:description.maml:para: Edit the PSReadLine History File
Use this function to edit the PSReadLine history file. This may be useful if you want to reset some of your autocomplete suggestions or remove commands that did not work.
Edit the WinGet settings file.
A shortcut to edit the WinGet settings file. This will create one if it does not already exist.
Get a filtered and de-duplicated list of commands from your history.

This function filters the output of Get-History to exclude a list of ignored commands and any commands that are less than 4 characters long. It can also be used to find all commands that match a given pattern. It is useful for quickly finding things from your history that you want to document or re-invoke.

maml:Description.maml:para: Show all command history without filtering anything out.

A string or array of strings to exclude. Commands that have these words in them will be excluded from the history output. The default ignored commands are: Get-History, Invoke-CommandHistory, Get-CommandHistory, clear.
A string or regex pattern to find in the command history. Commands that contain this pattern will be returned.
The Filter is passed to the -match operator, so it can be a simple string or a more complex regex pattern.
Show all command history without filtering anything out.

A string or array of strings to exclude. Commands that have these words in them will be excluded from the history output. The default ignored commands are: Get-History, Invoke-CommandHistory, Get-CommandHistory, clear.
A string or regex pattern to find in the command history. Commands that contain this pattern will be returned.
The Filter is passed to the -match operator, so it can be a simple string or a more complex regex pattern.

maml:alert.maml:para: Author: Sam Erde Version: 2.0.0 Modified: 2025-09-08

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will return all commands from your history that contain the word 'Disk'.
This will return all commands from your history that do not contain the words 'Get-Service' or 'Get-Process' (while also still filtering out the default ignore list).
This will return all commands from your history without any filtering.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the value of an environment variable.

The Get-EnvironmentVariable function retrieves the value of the specified environment variable or displays all environment variables. It is capable of finding variables by an exact name match or by using a regex pattern match. It can retrieve environment variables from the process, machine, and user targets. If no parameters are specified, all environment variables are returned from all targets.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the environment variable to retrieve.
The target (Process, Machine, User) to pull environment variables from. Multiple targets may be specified.
Optionally get all environment variables from all targets or all environment variables from one specified target. Process ID and process name will be included for process environment variables.
A regex pattern to find matching environment variable names.
The target (Process, Machine, User) to pull environment variables from. Multiple targets may be specified.
Optionally get all environment variables from all targets or all environment variables from one specified target. Process ID and process name will be included for process environment variables.
The name of the environment variable to retrieve.
A regex pattern to find matching environment variable names.
The target (Process, Machine, User) to pull environment variables from. Multiple targets may be specified.
Optionally get all environment variables from all targets or all environment variables from one specified target. Process ID and process name will be included for process environment variables.

maml:alert.maml:para: Author: Sam Erde Version: 1.0.0 Modified: 2025/03/05
About Environment Variables:

Variable names are case-sensitive on Linux and macOS, but not on Windows. PowerShell is case-insensitive by default and compensates for case-sensitivity on Linux and macOS. To make PowerShell case-sensitive, use the -CaseSensitive parameter when starting PowerShell.

Why is 'Target' used by .NET instead of the familiar 'Scope' parameter name? @IISResetMe (Mathias R. Jessen) explains: "Scope" would imply some sort of integrated hierarchy of env variables - that's not really the case. Target=Process translates to kernel32!GetEnvironmentVariable (which then in turn reads the PEB from the calling process), whereas Target={User,Machine} causes a registry lookup against environment data in either HKCU or HKLM.
The relevant sources for the User and Machine targets are in the registry at: - HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment
- HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment
See more at <https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_environment_variables>.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the value of the "UserName" environment variable from the process target.
Retrieves the value of the PATH environment variable from the machine target.
Get environment variables with names that begin with the letter "u" in any target.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the object type of each value in a hashtable.

This function retrieves the object type information of each value in a hashtable and returns System.Reflection.TypeInfo objects with additional ItemKey properties for identification. Results can be filtered to a specific key using the Key parameter.

maml:Description.maml:para: The hashtable to inspect.

Optional. Specify a specific hashtable key to get the type information for only that key's value. If not specified, type information for all keys will be returned. Tab completion is available for this parameter based on the keys in the provided hashtable.
The hashtable to inspect.

Optional. Specify a specific hashtable key to get the type information for only that key's value. If not specified, type information for all keys will be returned. Tab completion is available for this parameter based on the keys in the provided hashtable.

dev:type.maml:name: Type information objects for each hashtable entry, enhanced with an ItemKey property
and formatted using the PSPreworkout.HashtableValueType custom type.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function is useful for debugging hashtables and understanding the data types of their values. The output includes custom formatting via PSPreworkout.Format.ps1xml for improved readability.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns type information for all keys in the hashtable, sorted by key name.
Returns type information only for the "Key2" entry (System.String).
Demonstrates pipeline input usage to analyze hashtable value types.
Shows tab completion for keys, including proper quoting for keys with spaces.

maml:description.maml:para: Get all assemblies loaded in PowerShell.
Get all assemblies loaded in PowerShell.

maml:alert.maml:para: To Do: Add -Name parameter to get a specific one.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns a list of all loaded assemblies.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of installed PowerShell modules that have updates available in their source repository.
This function retrieves a list of installed PowerShell modules and checks for updates available in their source repository (e.g.: PowerShell Gallery or MAR).
If a pre-release version is installed, it checks the repository for a newer pre-release version or an equivalent (or higher) stable version. Otherwise, it only checks for stable updates.

maml:Description.maml:para: The module name or list of module names to check for updates. Wildcards and arrays are allowed. All modules ('*') are checked by default.
Display console output while returning module objects to the pipeline. When specified, the function will show available updates in the console and also return module objects for further processing.
The module name or list of module names to check for updates. Wildcards and arrays are allowed. All modules ('*') are checked by default.
Display console output while returning module objects to the pipeline. When specified, the function will show available updates in the console and also return module objects for further processing.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function uses Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet cmdlets for improved performance and functionality over the PowerShellGet module's cmdlets. The required module will be automatically installed if not present.

Scope Priority: The function prioritizes CurrentUser scope modules over AllUsers scope modules, which matches PowerShell's own behavior for importing or updating modules. When a module is installed in both scopes, it checks for updates against the CurrentUser version since that's what PowerShell would load by default. Use -Verbose to see which version and scope is being used for each module.
To Do: - Batch and "paginate" online checks to speed up. Find-PSResource can return multiple results in one request. - Add parameter for specifying specific repositories to check.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ModulesWithUpdate This command retrieves all installed PowerShell modules and checks for updates in their source repository.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ModulesWithUpdate -PassThru This command checks all installed modules for updates. It returns PSModuleInfo objects to the pipeline and displays console output about available updates.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ModulesWithUpdate -Name 'Pester', 'PSScriptAnalyzer' -PassThru | Update-PSResource This command checks specific modules for updates, displays console output about available updates, and pipes the results to Update-PSResource.

maml:description.maml:para: Download a portable version of PowerShell to run anywhere on demand.
This function helps you download a zipped copy of the latest version of PowerShell that can be run without needing to install it.

maml:Description.maml:para: The directory path to download the PowerShell zip or tar.gz file into. Do not include a filename for the download.
Extract the file after downloading.
The directory path to download the PowerShell zip or tar.gz file into. Do not include a filename for the download.
Extract the file after downloading.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Download the latest ZIP/TAR of PowerShell to your $HOME folder. It will be extracted into a folder that matches the filename of the compressed archive.

maml:description.maml:para: Get available type accelerators.
Get available type accelerators. These can be useful when trying to find or remember the different type accelerators that are available to use in PowerShell.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a specific type accelerator to get.
The name of a specific type accelerator to get.

maml:alert.maml:para: Thanks to Jeff Hicks (@JDHITSolutions) for helpful suggestions and improvements on this output!

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all type accelerators that begin with the string "ps".

This script installs the Microsoft.WinGet.CommandNotFound module and enables the required PowerShell features.
Install Oh My Posh and add it to your profile.
An over-engineered script to install Oh My Posh. This script exists as an exercise and is not intended for production use.

- winget - Install from winget (default). - msstore - Install from the Microsoft Store.

- chocolatey

- scoop
- winget

- Select - Lets you choose a nerd font from the list.

maml:description.maml:para: Install the Windows PowerShell ISE

This script installs Windows PowerShell ISE if it was not installed or previously removed. It includes a step that temporarily resets the Windows Automatic Update server source in the registry, which may resolve errors that some systems experience while trying to add Windows Capabilities.
Install Winget (beta)

Install WinGet on Windows Sandbox (or on builds of Windows 10 prior to build 1709 that did not ship with it preinstalled). This script exists mostly as an exercise, as there are already many ways to install WinGet.

maml:Description.maml:para: Path of the directory to save the downloaded packages in (optional).
Download the packages without installing them (optional).
Keep the downloaded packages (optional).
Path of the directory to save the downloaded packages in (optional).
Download the packages without installing them (optional).
Keep the downloaded packages (optional).

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new advanced function from a template.

This function creates a new function from a template and saves it to a file with the name of the function. It takes values for the function's synopsis, description, and alias as parameters and populates comment- based help for the new function automatically.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the new function to create. It is recommended to use ApprovedVerb-Noun for names.
A synopsis of the new function.
A description of the new function.
Optionally define an alias for the new function.
Name of the author of the script. Attempts to default to the 'FullName' property of the currently logged in user.
The path of the directory to save the new script in.
Optionally skip validation of the script.
The verb to use for the function name.
The noun to use for the function name.
A synopsis of the new function.
A description of the new function.
Optionally define an alias for the new function.
Name of the author of the script. Attempts to default to the 'FullName' property of the currently logged in user.
The path of the directory to save the new script in.
Optionally skip validation of the script.
The name of the new function to create. It is recommended to use ApprovedVerb-Noun for names.
The verb to use for the function name.
The noun to use for the function name.
A synopsis of the new function.
A description of the new function.
Optionally define an alias for the new function.
Name of the author of the script. Attempts to default to the 'FullName' property of the currently logged in user.
The path of the directory to save the new script in.
Optionally skip validation of the script.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-ScriptFromTemplate -Name 'Get-Demo' -Synopsis 'Get a demo.' -Description 'This function gets a demo.' -Alias 'Get-Sample'

maml:description.maml:para: Convert an object to JSON and write it to a file.
This function converts an object to JSON and writes the output to the specified file. By default, it saves the file with the name of the object that you provided to the function.

maml:Description.maml:para: The object to convert to JSON. [ValidateScript({ if (-not [string]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace($ ) -and -not [string]::IsNullOrEmpty($ )) { $true } })]
Full path and filename to save the JSON to. [ValidatePattern('\.json$')] # Do not require a JSON extension.
Depth to serialize the object into JSON. Default is 2.
The object to convert to JSON. [ValidateScript({ if (-not [string]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace($ ) -and -not [string]::IsNullOrEmpty($ )) { $true } })]
Depth to serialize the object into JSON. Default is 2.
Full path and filename to save the JSON to. [ValidatePattern('\.json$')] # Do not require a JSON extension.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Writes $TestObject as JSON to "$HOME/TestObject.json".
Writes $TestObject as JSON to C:\Temp\report.json.
Writes $TestObject as JSON to TestObject.json in the current working directory of the file system.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the font for your consoles in Windows.

Set-ConsoleFont allows you to set the font for all of your registered Windows consoles (Windows PowerShell, Windows Terminal, PowerShell, or Command Prompt). It provides tab-autocomplete for the font parameter, listing all of the Nerd Fonts and monospace fonts installed in Windows.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the font to set for your consoles in Windows.
The name of the font to set for your consoles in Windows.

maml:description.maml:para: Show an object without its empty properties.
This function shows the properties of an object with all of its empty properties filtered out.

maml:Description.maml:para: The object to show.
The object to show.

maml:alert.maml:para: I am grateful to Jeffrey Hicks for guiding me towards an understanding of how to complete this function and for providing even nicer code than I started with. I encourage you to reach out to him for PowerShell training and subscribe to his newsletter! 🙏
https://jdhitsolutions.github.io/ https://www.linkedin.com/in/jefferyhicks/ https://twitter.com/JeffHicks

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $Desk = [PSCustomObject]@{ Model = 'PSDesk' Height = $null Width = $null Colors = @('Black', 'Gray') Adjustable = $true } $Object = New-Object -TypeName PSObject -Property $Desk Show-WithoutEmptyProperty -Object $Object
